[%][%Credibility]
You have a lead, a prospect that wants to engage. You’ve set the meeting and are ready to fire! Your next objective is to __establish credibility__.

Never assume people are familiar with you. Even though a lead contacts you, it doesn't necessarily mean that they are aware of your qualifications and level of experience. They could just as well be ‘shopping’, having reached out to multiple people in your industry. You must establish your credibility and let them know how much you are worth.

You cannot feel or touch credibility; it is an intangible concept. Credibility is an impression that people form about you. It is a feeling of reliability, plausibility, and perceived expertise that communicates to others that you are able to offer beneficial solutions and that you can be relied upon to guide them in making wise decisions. Credibility is required for the development and expansion of mutual relationships.
The foundation of every relationship is credibility; the more you have, the more your prospect will want to interact with you. Your likelihood of success rises as your credibility grows because it makes potential clients and customers feel more at ease. You can establish credibility by asking the right questions.

[%][%Implication questions]
Besides needs and desires, we also want the customer telling us why those issues are important. By using implications questions, you can move your sales conversations from simply focusing on the facts and information to actually comprehending the emotional drivers that will take place if a pressing problem is not properly resolved. Remember that decisions are made based on emotion, considerably more so than radically or analytically. It’s the implications will ultimately justify the decision to move forward with you. The urgency for a solution will grow by the increasing number of implications. Why? Because the more issues and implications you uncover, the more reasons the buyer has to buy from you.


It’s pretty simple to uncover implications. Once you discovered an issue, you simply follow up and ask one of the following:

- How do you mean?
- How so?
- What happened next?
- Like what?
- How does that work?
- Tell me more.

__Tip__: don’t ask “what” do you mean. Instead, ask “How” do you mean.

When you identify a problem, you should delve deeper by asking at least three implication questions to get to the bottom of the prospect's real feelings, thoughts, and concerns. This is how you really get to understand the problem or desire and its emotional influence. These implications are for you to combine with your intangible value. Asking implications also increases the sense of urgency surrounding the issue, which is a good reason to proceed with the purchase. Additionally, it will greatly increase your credibility!

What I recommend you to do before you go into a meeting, is to make a list of needs or desires, the so-called __decision-makers__. For each item, write down potential implications. How? Think about how the customer might value this thing or this issue. Try to get a minimum of 5 implications.
For example: if home security is the issue, implications are: personal safety, fire, financial loss, peace of mind.

[%][%Micro-commitments]
Micro-commitment: A commitment to a decision or action at the end of each conversation to help you advance the sale faster and eliminate redundancy in follow-up actions and conversations (N. Bleeke).

Without engagement, a prospect won't become a client. Throughout the sales process, engagement is necessary, and micro-commitments help you achieve it. There is a much higher chance that you will close the deal and get fewer objections when prospects consistently invest time, effort, and emotion in the process. The investment effect of time, money, effort and emotion is leveraged. With the micro-commitment yeses, you move from momentum to momentum. And the great thing is: Prospects actually appreciate and prefer micro-commitments. It gives them direction, clarity and makes you look professional and organized.

Never leave a conversation without a clear course of action. Statements such as “I’ll call you next week” or “I’ll email you the next steps” are terrible and set you up for failure. Does the person actually have time next week? Nor is there any form of commitment from the other side. [%][%Because statement]
As the name reveals, a because statement is a sentence in which you employ the words “because” to make an argument. An effective because statement should create a connection between the problems your prospect is facing and how you can assist them, using their language, not yours. The latter is key because it causes them to feel that you get them. Everyone desires to be understood (J. Blount).

Check out this example study, that proves the value of asking questions and because statements. It’s a study on human behavior conducted by Ellen Langer from Harvard, published in the book Virtual
Selling from Jebb Blount.
“Because compels people to comply with your request.” E. Langer discovered that when she politely asked to jump in front of the person waiting for the copier without giving a reason would lead to a
‘Yes’ 60 percent of the time. __Excuse me, I have 5 pages. May I use the copier?__
However, when she would provide valid reasons as well, the ‘Yes’ increased to a stunning 94 percent.
__Excuse me, I have 5 pages. May I use the copier? Because I am in a hurry__.
Interestingly, when she gave a nonsensical reason, __Excuse me, I have 5 pages. May I use the copier?
Because I have copies to make__, still 93 percent said ‘Yes’.”

So, simply provide reason and people will likely say yes. It’s therefore recommended to use a because statement in your micro-commitment question as well. You can combine a because statement with the Solution question. For every argument or commitment when you want to convince the prospect, design because statements. It will make your life much easier :)

Another aspect to stand out and gain engagement (where micro commitments is all about), is to understand that how you convey your message is as important as to __what__ you say. As important as your product is how you present it to customers. Which is great, because it’s another opportunity for you to make a difference. 

The words we use while we communicate are crucial because __people think in pictures, not in words__. Imagine I told you I bought a fast red car last year. Are you thinking of the letters F A S T  R E D  C A R or did you have an image of a red Ferrari in your mind? Visualization enables humans to make decisions quickly. Therefore we need to frame our story with words that allow people to create clear pictures (H. Kensett).

The art of storytelling is a fantastic tool for this. A good story will touch the listener's emotions and leave them with a lasting impression. Facts alone will not suffice. A story on the other hand aids in the creation of images, making the story much more memorable for customers. In fact, information presented in the form of a story is 22 times more likely to be remembered than information presented as simple facts. Our brains start to sync up with the storyteller's when we listen to a story; the same brain regions start to fire simultaneously in both of our heads. Another amazing upside is that stories have a direct correlation with trust. And as we know, trust is an extremely important factor that determines the likelihood of doing business with one another. Furthermore, the brain uses the same regions to comprehend stories as it does to comprehend other people, which is another fantastic aspect of stories. Because of this, stories enable the listener to identify with the storyteller and gain a deeper understanding of their "who," "what," and "why." The great thing about stories is that they are usually easier to tell than selling benefits. Benefits lack heart and soul (M. Pollard). Moreover, a story is about the implications, which is crucial in the selling process!

**- Good takeaway is that the more sensory the words, the more the brain engages and thus, remembers.

What are sensory words? Words that evoke a sense of a smell for example (e.g. perfume and coffee). Those words cause different areas of the brain to light up than when the same people read non-sensory words (e.g. chair and key).**

[%][%What’s your story?]
So - it’s become clear that a story is a vital part of your sales system. All you have to do now is find one or two stories that somehow convey the value of what you sell and tell them well. Sounds easy right? Well, for most people it’s not that easy to compile a story just like that. I recommend you to follow the following structure, it should give you an idea of how to start your story.

•1 You ask a lot of questions in your selling process. These questions already convey your story. Answer all the questions your customers give you and you have a framework ready to go. Moreover, rely on previous experiences, successes and testimonials. Those stories lay a good foundation.
•1 Start with the problem, the situation and the emotional state. Describe the situation, including any worries, personal stress, anxiety, or frustration. The prospect must identify with and recognize themselves in the story.
•1 Evaluation and implementation. Describe your analysis of the situation and your recommendations for handling it. Discuss the steps necessary to reach the solution and the time frame involved. Just tell the story to inspire, don't lecture.
•1 The result. When you begin telling the result, it’s good to start with quickly highlighting the problem one more time. “So Mike went from 40 kilos overweight, struggling to get around himself every day, to losing not only 40 but 45 kilos.” Just this doesn’t do it though. You need to include the intangible value as well, the true benefit. “So Mike went from 40 kilos overweight, struggling to get around himself every day, to losing not only 40 but 45 kilos, now being not only happy with his weight but it also boosted his confidence and is a happier father to his children.”
•1 The lesson of the tale. a justification for why the potential customer needs your product. “That’s why it’s so vitally important to have a good structure in place. Mike could have said, ‘That’s a lot of work’, but if you take into account what Mike had to do before to be happy, it’s a lot less work now.”

Additional tips to write a good story:
• The brain is more engaged and therefore more likely to remember words that are sensory-rich. What are sensory words? Words that link readers to the five senses: touch, sight, sound, smell, and taste. Such words cause different areas of the brain to light up compared to reading non-sensory words. Please find Appendix X for a list of sensory words, ready for your to use!
• Use simple and concrete language. Words and phrases that anyone can understand, even those without specialized knowledge!
• Using metaphors is another tactic. Customers can understand concepts more quickly when metaphors are used.
• Adjectives and adverbs can be used to increase energy. Incredibly, rapidly, exciting, extremely, etc. Be careful, overuse these words and you sound unrealistic.

[%][%Eliminate No]
The micro-commitment process doesn’t end when the meeting ends. Your prospect needs your assistance in risk analysis, problem solving, and removing anxiety. If you do not, it will make the potential customer uncomfortable, and they decide not to use your solution as a result. Therefore, it’s essential that you clearly define who’s doing what by when and truly follow up.

One option to eliminate fears and concerns is to include __review sessions__. A specific meeting to go over your proposal together with your prospect. How do you arrange that?

1. Starting commitment

“Thank you for meeting me today. I'm going to demonstrate X during this meeting, which should last no longer than an hour. At the end of this meeting, we'll schedule a second meeting to address all of your concerns and make sure you are completely confident in your decision to proceed.”

This is great! Does it sound salesy? For a lot of people it does. But you have to turn the tables here and put yourself in the customer’s shoes. Remember the dentist example?
You want clarity, you want direction, you want security. This is great.

2. Ending commitment
At the end of a Discovery meeting you need to ask for the commitment again:
    • “You are undoubtedly going to have questions and concerns. I want to be sure that I am available to answer your queries and allay your worries. What do you think about this time next week?”
    • “As you look at other proposals, you may see different ideas that you like. Let’s schedule a quick session to address and answer any questions to confidently move forward.”

Do you notice the nice competitor’s edge here as well?

In addition, if you do address these concerns, you establish a great level of credibility. The kind of partner you'll be will be evident to the prospects firsthand. He'll be able to see for himself that you're there to support him through difficult decisions, respond to his inquiries, provide guidance, and address issues. You remain involved, available, and engaged.

3. Tailor
Your goal is to work together on converting your solution into "our" solution during the review meeting. Because such sessions also allow you to make changes and modifications to your proposal.
You and the client jointly customize your solution to meet their needs.

• “What would you like to be changed?
• “What else is required to complete this exactly as you want it?”
• "How can we improve this even more?"

Anthony Iannarino (The Lost Art of Closing) told me this amazing story. It’s about billionaire entrepreneur Ross Perot, who built a company called EDS. When a potential client was close to making a decision, Perot liked to gather all the interested parties and distribute his proposal along with red pens and highlighters. He would explain that he had made every effort to create the precise solution they required, but he was concerned that it wasn't perfect. He wasn't confident that he had not missed anything, or that they collectively hadn't missed something crucial. The stakeholders were then instructed to review the solution and identify any areas where they felt it needed improvement. He would implement the suggested changes after the meeting. He would then return another day to present the updated solution. 

Isn’t this an amazing example of ensuring to not get a No from your prospect?
You collaborate and build consensus. It shows you’re caring. Yes, it’s a lengthy process but it secures a lengthy relationship and ‘lengthy’ deals (a lot of money). You’re already so far in the sales process, what extra step would you take, how far would you go, for a lot of money?

[%][%Emotions]
The human decision-making process is inevitably accompanied by objections. When someone objects, our natural instinct is to withdraw into ourselves. That’s why we stumble over our words. A key component of objections is emotion. The likelihood of success is influenced by how we collaborate with them. The person who exercises the most emotional restraint in a sales conversation has the best chance of getting the desired result. Because both selling and buying are human processes, your interactions with the buyer will likely be greatly influenced by disruptive emotions.

To make a comparison, let’s look at the sport and in particular tennis. Roger Federer has ruled men’s tennis for years. So have Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic. What do they have in common, besides the obvious fact that they possess great talents, work extremely hard and are committed? They all control their emotions extremely well - especially when tension is the highest! They might yell when they win a point but they never scream when they lose a point. And that’s the key - they control their emotions so well, that they enable themselves to be at their best when it’s needed and focus on the core task that is at hand.

In sales, we treat objections as if they are rational and logical too frequently. But according to science, human decision-making, including objections, begins with emotion and then moves to logic. Due to this, we must concentrate on maintaining emotional control in both ourselves and our clients. Objections are emotional. 

Controlling your own emotions can be difficult. You need to build-in situational awareness. Realizing that the emotion is present is the first step. When you know it, you can start controlling it. Begin by concentrating on your breathing. Concentrate on feeling confident and say what you want to say. “Hey I feel this emotion. That’s okay. I need to focus now.” Make this choice and think positively (intentional decision). 

Confidence and assertive talking and asking will give you more deals and with that, your confidence grows. The opposite is very true as well unfortunately. If you let your emotions take over, you will lose, all the time.

[%][%Objection types]
There are different types of objections, mainly related to the phase of the sales process.

•1 __Prospecting__
Prospecting is the first step in the sales process, which consists of identifying potential customers, aka prospects. Even though a prospect requested information, it doesn’t always mean that they want to be contacted. Think of it as walking into a store while shopping. Sometimes you just want to look around yourself and not be harassed by a salesperson showing all the different types of shorts.
•1 __Red Herrings__
This is when a prospect brings up a pointless subject or issue to sidetrack the conversation from the main subject at hand.
•1 __Micro-Commitment objections__
You must never, ever leave a conversation without a firm next step. It’s therefore that micro-commitments matter. You need to be confident while asking and showing your customer the value in moving on.
•1 __Buying commitment objections__
Almost at the end of the process, almost reached success and then they hit you with multiple buying objections. Pricing, budget, timing, superiors, competition and terms and conditions, are a few examples of buying objections.

[%][%Prospecting objections]
1. Ledge
The first step in dealing with a prospecting objection is called a ledge. A ledge is a pause and creates a little room in the conversation. It can be a statement, acknowledgement, agreement or question. This is effective because it is simple. You can memorize it, leading to automatic responses. It also sends a message that they’ve been heard, that you’re open and want to understand it. Acknowledging doesn’t mean agreeing, focus on that you hear the concern.

• How so?
• I appreciate knowing/hearing/sharing
• Understandably.
• That’s why I called.
• I thought you might bring that up.
• Good point. I wanted to talk about that.
• I can see where you're coming from.
• That's how a lot of people feel.
• That is reasonable

This is that moment that you take a break, breath and gain control over your emotions. Focus and remain calm as well as confident. Be careful not to name their emotion, avoid using words like "frustrated" or "afraid". Practice this!

2. Disrupt
Doing the unexpected is how you flip the script and win the customer over after ledging. How? Transform the objection by sending a statement or a question. Here are some great examples that I learned from Jebb Blount:
• “Just send me some info”.
	• Fantastic! I'm pleased to hear that you want to know more. Since there is so much information available, and I don't want to overwhelm you—assuming you have a busy schedule. Would you please elaborate on the details you require?
• I’m not interested.
	• That makes sense. The majority of people aren't initially, until they realize how I can help them. To be honest, I'm not even sure if my service would be a good fit for you. However, I believe it would, so let's check.
• If a prospect claims to be busy, don’t argue.
	• That's exactly why I called; I anticipated that you'd be busy and wanted to schedule a time that would be more suitable for you.
• The prospect is already in contact with a competitor.
	• Good. If you’re getting good quality for good prices, no need to consider changing. All I want is a few minutes of your time to get to know you better and determine whether or not we are even a good fit. I’ll at least provide you with a competitive quote that helps you keep those other guys honest.

Never argue with the prospect. It does the contrary of what you want.

3. Ask
Even if you provide a good turnaround, you still need to ask. Once you received more information from the prospect, just ask what you initially wanted to ask.
• Let’s schedule a meeting, how do you look next Wednesday at 11am?
• Let me send you a brochure and I will call you next week, so you'll have time to read it. What about Tuesday again?

All it really is, is a 3-step process. Make yourself familiar with it. Because in the heat of the moment, you want this to flow automatically. So prepare yourself. Make a script. One that you feel comfortable with. That sounds natural to you.

[%][%Red Herring objections]
Moving past Red Herrings requires even more emotional control. Hence, another simple system.

1. Ledge
Again, you pause, collect your emotions and let the prospect know that you’ve heard them. Taking notes is a fantastic additional strategy for doing this. In addition to giving you time to reflect and pause, writing down what they say lets them know that you value what they have to say.

2. Park
My advice is to ignore Red Herrings unless they are brought up again. Although they hardly ever do. After expressing your concern, simply ask an off-topic, open-ended question to pique the prospect's interest in something else. If you deal with it on the spot, make it short and sweet and explain that you will further elaborate later on. Let’s say you’re shooting videos for weddings. You are about to start your first proper meeting with your client and then they ask:
• Prospect: Before we start, what about the costs? We’re not sure if we want a video and the costs can’t be too high.
• You: Oh really yeah, I understand that’s important to you. I’ll write it down. Let me ask, what are your wishes and requirements for your wedding? I’d like to learn more about you two. 
Or
• Oh really yeah, I understand that’s important to you. I’ll write it down. Oh BTW, when was the big day exactly again?

[%][%Micro-Commitment Objections]
Even though a micro-commitment mostly is a good reason to move forward, you will get an objection every now and then. In that case, you haven’t transferred the value of moving forward well enough. You therefore need to illustrate the value of moving to the next step.

•1 Ledge.
Collect your emotions and say that you have heard and understood the customer.
•1 Explain value.
Explain the purpose of the next step and demonstrate how the prospect will benefit from it.
•1 Ask.
Ask again after you've outlined the benefit.

A piece of advice: Don’t skip steps! Even though you’d like an objection to prevent it from happening, skipping steps will certainly end you up with more objections later on in the process, which are much harder to turn around.

[%][%Competitor objections]
My preference is to not talk about competition at all. Being asked however is different of course.

Don’t be surprised the get questions such as:
• What distinguishes your product from other products in the market?
• Why should I pick you over X competitor?
• What makes you the best?

It's wise to learn more information rather than pounce on your product's advantages right away. So in your response, pose a query and ask:
• What degree of product familiarity do you have?
• What do you know about competitor X?
• What qualifies as "the best"?

Never respond with an elevator pitch. I always like to give my competitor a compliment. I usually say something along the lines of: “Well, I don’t work at Car XYZ but they seem to do pretty well, so I am sure they must be a good car dealer.”

From there, you obviously want to position yourself in a good spot. So instead of talking about the competitor, I emphasize what we do better. “Well, you know Mr Mike, there are many car dealers out where you could essentially buy the same car. One approach is to offer a discount. That’s how we take a different approach. I know that when you have an issue with your car at Car XYZ, they work with a partner garage. We don’t do that. We help you out right here at our facility, to ensure you get the best possible service possible. And that’s all included in the price.”

Now you are in a great position to communicate the benefits of your proposed solution. How? Answer the implications (not just the features) that you solve!

Is the competitor cheaper? Own it. "That's correct. They always are.” You now acknowledge something that the prospect was going to use as an argument against your offer. From there, again, accentuate your value vs pricing. “Although I don't work there, I imagine it to be a good company. What I do know is that we invest more than they do in generating the results our clients need as we handle everything in-house, we don’t outsource and control the quality that you will receive as our customer. Moreover, is a lower price more important to you than a lower overall cost? Because by investing more at the start, you won’t have these expenses: A,B,C (e.g. maintenance). Eventually and essentially saving you money in the long run :)”

Lastly, a piece of advice regarding competition: Don’t bad-mouth your competitors, even if they do so about you. Don’t join the mud fight. Customers have enough common sense to understand that trashing your competitor is not a nice thing. It also says something about you and your personality. Would you want to work with such a person/company?

Is the competitor cheaper? Own it. "That's correct. They always are.” You now acknowledge something that the prospect was going to use as an argument against your offer. From there, again, accentuate your value vs pricing. “Although I don't work there, I imagine it to be a good company. What I do know is that we invest more than they do in generating the results our clients need as we handle everything in-house, we don’t outsource and control the quality that you will receive as our customer. Moreover, is a lower price more important to you than a lower overall cost? Because by investing more at the start, you won’t have these expenses: A,B,C (e.g. maintenance). Eventually and essentially saving you money in the long run :)”

Lastly, a piece of advice regarding competition: Don’t bad-mouth your competitors, even if they do so about you. Don’t join the mud fight. Customers have enough common sense to understand that trashing your competitor is not a nice thing. It also says something about you and your personality. Would you want to work with such a person/company?

A story? Yes. Instead of tackling an objection head-on, an objection story might be better.

A story about a similar customer that had similar concerns but ultimately made the decision to proceed, which is why they're so happy they did today. Use a name, to make it personal and appealing. “I had a client, Mike, …”

Without directly disputing the customer's claims or assertions, such a story allays their worries, confirms that they have a real fear, but mostly provides them with evidence that you've helped others deal with similar situations. Prospects can easily contest figures or claimed benefits, but it's much more difficult for them to dispute stories about your past clients.

[#What if they say “No”?]

[.article:bitmark++]
[@id:295281]
You won’t get a 100 percent conversionrate. That’s a dreamworld. So you will get No’s. And that’s okay. Avoid being defensive, acting surprised, or showing signs of unhappiness (even though you are, because it sucks). Instead, find a solution by asking the reason.
• If you aren't prepared to proceed, either we haven't done something that still needs to be done, or something on your end has changed. Would you mind telling me what changed?
• What should we do about this, in your opinion, so that we can all move forward together?
• All of the problems that led us to this point are still present and continue to be important. I worry that things will get worse if we don't move forward. How can we resolve this problem together in the best possible way?

And if you miss the sale, just remember; no sales at all is much more painful than just one prospect that says no.

[#Prepare]

[.article:bitmark++]
[@id:295283]
You might, or should, have noticed that one common technique to overcome objections is to take a break. Take a breath and realize that objections are natural. Objections are okay.

Then you use your standard-stop-phrase. A response that you automatically use whenever your client objects. This sentence is so well practiced, it rolls off the tongue automatically. A sentence such as: “I perfectly understand and the last thing I want to do is to waste any of our time, however…” 

Practice a few of those sentences a lot, so that when you are faced with a sudden objection, you have this at hand and, since you know it so well, you still sound like you. This sentence gives you the time and space to think about your next step.

And practice!
• Identify probable objections and questions upfront. Make a list.
• Write down clarifying questions
• Prepare proof or validation

You need to learn your responses by hard. You need to be able to stabilize yourself in the heat of the moment and have an automatic response. Learn by hard and practise!
